articles.headline: Wall Street Opens Its Wallet to Keep Talent. It’s Not Always Enough.
articles.snippet: Banks are raising pay to fend off investment firms, fintechs and crypto start-ups. Still, leaving is often about something other than “always having more and more.”
articles.abstract: Banks are raising pay to fend off investment firms, fintechs and crypto start-ups. Still, leaving is often about something other than “always having more and more.”
articles.lead_paragraph: It didn’t matter that Citigroup paid Amy Wu Stratton $450,000 in 2021 — her most lucrative year ever — to work with some of its biggest private equity clients. It didn’t even matter that she was on track for a promotion that could double her pay.

articles.headline: McConnell Denounces R.N.C. Censure of Jan. 6 Panel Members
articles.snippet: Senator Mitch McConnell joined a chorus of Republicans distancing themselves from the committee’s action, describing the Capitol riot as “a violent insurrection.”
articles.abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell joined a chorus of Republicans distancing themselves from the committee’s action, describing the Capitol riot as “a violent insurrection.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, pushed back hard on Tuesday against the Republican Party’s censure of Representatives Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger and its characterization of the Jan. 6 riot as “legitimate political discourse,” saying the riot was a “violent insurrection.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Dropping Indoor Mask Mandate, New York Joins Blue States Easing Covid Rules
articles.snippet: After a scare in November, New Jersey’s governor and other Democratic leaders held back-channel talks over lifting mandates and helping voters impatient with restrictions reclaim a sense of normalcy.
articles.abstract: After a scare in November, New Jersey’s governor and other Democratic leaders held back-channel talks over lifting mandates and helping voters impatient with restrictions reclaim a sense of normalcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul will drop New York’s stringent indoor mask mandate on Wednesday, ending a requirement that businesses ask customers for proof of full vaccination or require mask wearing at all times, and marking a turning point in the state’s coronavirus response, according to three people briefed on her decision.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Local Papers Find Hints of Success With Online Subscriptions
articles.snippet: The numbers still pale in comparison with print’s heyday, but the increase is giving some publishers an unusual feeling: hope.
articles.abstract: The numbers still pale in comparison with print’s heyday, but the increase is giving some publishers an unusual feeling: hope.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the hedge fund Alden Global Capital bid to buy the newspaper chain Lee Enterprises in November, many journalists at Lee’s newspapers opposed a sale because Alden had slashed newsroom costs at the newspapers it owns.

articles.headline: Where’s Liz Cheney? The Wyoming Republican’s Exile From Wyoming Republicans
articles.snippet: The congresswoman hasn’t attended Republican Party events in person in her state in years, amid a wave of local conservative hostility. “I’m not going to convince the crazies,” she said.
articles.abstract: The congresswoman hasn’t attended Republican Party events in person in her state in years, amid a wave of local conservative hostility. “I’m not going to convince the crazies,” she said.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: The Real Reason America Doesn’t Have Enough Truck Drivers
articles.snippet: A 1,000-mile journey through the middle of America reveals the fundamental reason for truck driver shortages: It is a job full of stress, physical deprivation and loneliness.
articles.abstract: A 1,000-mile journey through the middle of America reveals the fundamental reason for truck driver shortages: It is a job full of stress, physical deprivation and loneliness.
articles.lead_paragraph: A faint winter sun slides toward the frozen scrub as Stephen Graves guides his tractor-trailer across the cracked pavement of a truck stop parking lot in southern Oklahoma. Exhausted from another 400 miles behind the wheel, he needs the restroom. But mostly he needs an answer to the same question that dogs him nearly every day as darkness falls: Where can he park his rig for the night?
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and George Etheredge

articles.headline: China’s Anti-Graft Show Is Educational, With Unintended Lessons
articles.snippet: A documentary created to celebrate the success of China’s anti-corruption campaign instead has aired the dirty laundry of the Communist Party.
articles.abstract: A documentary created to celebrate the success of China’s anti-corruption campaign instead has aired the dirty laundry of the Communist Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: One by one, the officials spoke candidly on camera about how they abused their power and accumulated enormous wealth. They looked relaxed, confident and even happy as they described bribes, kickbacks and other perks of corruption.

articles.headline: Rivian Loses Its Shine as Investors Fret About Production Delays
articles.snippet: The electric vehicle maker’s stock surged after a public offering last fall but has since plunged, in part because the company failed to meet its 2021 goals.
articles.abstract: The electric vehicle maker’s stock surged after a public offering last fall but has since plunged, in part because the company failed to meet its 2021 goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rivian, a maker of electric vehicles that aspires to compete with Tesla, completed an initial public offering last year that raised nearly $14 billion. Its shares quickly soared, and the company briefly had a stock market value that was nearly twice that of Ford Motor.
